item.title: Incubyte DevOps Assessment
item.description: Hello there, Welcome to the Incubyte DevOps Assessment! Through this assessment, we want to evaluate how well you can work with CI/CD tools across the board.

item.title: Your daily productivity test
item.description: Are you a software developer? How can you be more effective on this journey of being a craftsman?

item.title: Project Kickstart Checklist
item.description: The Checklist Manifesto by Atul Gawande, walks us through the benefits of the humble checklist. He talks about how checklists of “dumb stuff” can save us from disasters in life and death situations.

item.title: Understanding Technical debt!
item.description: The term “Technical Debt” was coined by Ward Cunningham (one of the authors of Agile Manifesto).

item.title: Pair Programming — How it works!
item.description: Have you ever come across a bug that had complex logic, and was incredibly hard to fix?

item.title: Incubyte TDD Assessment
item.description: Hello there and welcome to the Incubyte TDD Kata! This assessment is the first step in our recruiting process and will be followed by two pair programming/discussion sessions.

item.title: Ideas for Successful Agile Teams
item.description: Agile is the most discussed software development methodology, and probably most widely accepted as the way forward for modern software development teams.

item.description: It all started when— unbeknownst to the world, a series of lockdowns changed the way India Inc.

item.title: 12 Books Developers Must Read
item.description: Books are a massive source of knowledge. Before we list all the books here, we want to discuss why we think it’s essential for programmers to read them.

item.title: Clean Agile with Uncle Bob: A Summary
item.description: An overview: I recently attended an online session on Clean Agile, organized by O’Reilly publication.And guess who was the speaker?

item.title: How to contribute to open-source project: A beginner's guide
item.description: Are you a first-time contributor? Are you wondering how to start contributing to OSS? Well, this guide is made for you.

item.title: Benefits and Challenges of Open-Source Development
item.description: Open-source software (OSS) is the holy grail for developers. It is a hub of innovation through intense collaboration in this era of agile software development.

item.title: Do not assume that technical debt is a problem with your code
item.description: Ever saw SonarQube laden with thousands of maintainability and security issues? Looking at those dashboards, we often believe we’re looking at the code’s state, but there is more to it.

item.title: Not All Tests are the Same
item.description: On multiple occasions, I have worked on projects where I learned how critical testing is and that not all tests are the same.

item.title: Remote Onboarding & Immersion at Incubyte
item.description: Employee onboarding is the important process of introducing newly hired employees to the organisation. It is everything that leads up to the employee’s total immersion into the organisation’s culture.

item.title: The Battle of Source Control
item.description: git pull origin develop git checkout -b feature/shiny-new-branch It’s the start of a sprint, and you have picked up a new User Story.

item.title: Why Incubyte?
item.description: Quality is usually an implicit requirement when it comes to developing software. Users ask for a beautiful UI, outstanding performance, and the functionality they need, but quality is never on the list - it is just expected!

item.title: Do not Release Code Without Automated Tests
item.description: Most projects that I see facing serious problems lack tests. You should write tests for two things

item.title: Do not Get so busy that you stop learning
item.description: Learning is the most vital part of a software developer’s life. Being so busy that one stops learning is neither desirable nor helpful to one’s career.

item.title: Do not Optimize Prematurely
item.description: Once again, you would think that the software development community has moved past this point, but I still get many teammates who want to “save memory” using HashMaps instead of POJOs.

item.title: Do not Show Separate Estimate for Unit Testing
item.description: Once I was asked in an interview (I was the interviewer!) What do you do in situations where the customers don’t want you to write test cases, or they want you to deprioritize the activity of writing test cases.

item.title: How We Hire Software Craftspeople
item.description: Any organization is the sum of its people and employees are its main spokespeople. Human capital is our most valued asset.

item.title: Security Practices for Postgres Web Application
item.description: Data security is when protective measures are put in place to keep unauthorsized access out of computers, websites, and databases.

item.title: Working at Incubyte
item.description: At Incubyte we strongly believe in finding the right talent, helping them to unleash their maximum capacity, and then getting out of their way to let them do what they do best.

item.title: Do not Copy and paste code to minimize the impact:
item.description: Have you ever seen code in your module, which was so complex that you decided to copy and paste it entirely rather than changing it to accommodate your requirement?

item.title: Do not Fall for faux agile
item.description: Enough ink is already spilled on this topic, nevertheless talking about it once again may not hurt.

item.title: Feedback & Rapid Prototyping
item.description: “No fixed direction remains valid for long” - Extreme Programming Explained by Kent Beck

item.title: Planning & Communication
item.description: One of our primary process goals is to make frequent, small releases of our working software.

item.title: Technology Platforms & Business Economics
item.description: Early in a project, we have to decide which platforms we’ll use. Which platforms depend on our ideas for solving the users’ problems.
